channel.title: Sony Admits Private PSN Info Has Been Stolen - All Of It
channel.description:
While I have no issues yet, I suggest EVERYBODY with a Sony product best be keeping your bank account open for the next while, or report your debit/credit card (if used) as stolen and get a new one (i am doing this in the morning to both of myn). I found this on the site I goto about PSP hacking, and this was just posted. I figured since we have some PS3 and PSP fans here (im only PSP) this should be shared on here.
While it doesn't say much about what exactly happened, a new update to the PlayStation Network disaster reveals that somebody, somewhere, managed to break into the system and get hold of your private information - all of it. If you're reading this, then you're almost certainly aware that over the past week, Sony's PlayStation Network has been suffering some rather severe technical difficulties. Sony is apparently still trying to figure out what's going on, or at the very least isn't yet ready to disclose all the facts, and there's still no ETA for a resumption of services. But in a new status update, Sony revealed that PlayStation Network and Qriocity user data has in fact been compromised. And not just your PSN ID. "Although we are still investigating the details of this incident, we believe that an unauthorized person has obtained the following information that you provided: name, address (city, state, zip), country, email address, birthdate, PlayStation Network/Qriocity password and login, and handle/PSN online ID," Sony's Patrick Seybold wrote in a message being sent to all registered PSN account holders. "It is also possible that your profile data, including purchase history and billing address (city, state, zip), and your PlayStation Network/Qriocity password security answers may have been obtained." "If you have authorized a sub-account for your dependent, the same data with respect to your dependent may have been obtained. While there is no evidence at this time that credit card data was taken, we cannot rule out the possibility," he continued. "If you have provided your credit card data through PlayStation Network or Qriocity, out of an abundance of caution we are advising you that your credit card number (excluding security code) and expiration date may have been obtained." In other words, not to put too fine a point on it, whoever broke into Sony's systems got everything - everything. At this point, the situation appears to have shifted from a dispassionately amusing debacle to an absolute balls-out train wreck, certainly not helped by the fact that Sony may have sat on this information for nearly a full week before letting the public know just how badly it was compromised. Sony advised PSN members to pay special attention to their credit card account statements and other related information, be alert for email, telephone and postal scams and change all passwords as soon as possible, which is to say, whenever Sony gets the PSN working again. It also regrets any inconvenience
source: [url=http://www.escapistmagazine.com/news/view/109568-Sony-Admits-Private-PSN-Info-Has-Been-Stolen-All-Of-It]The Escapist : News : Sony Admits Private PSN Info Has Been Stolen - All Of It[/url]

item.title: Sony Admits Private PSN Info Has Been Stolen - All Of It
item.dc:creator: @CoonHunter CoonHunter
item.description:
@CoonHunter wrote:

[quote=“drubrkletern, post:63, topic:392746”][quote author=CoonHunter link=topic=489915.msg3588728#msg3588728 date=1304392537]

+1 if you’re glad Anon won

This wasn’t Anon.

As said, it was done via a hacker that actually found a debug mode within the PSN via the PSP. Using this debug mode, most likely wrote a plugin to dump any data he could get threw the USB onto his PC or something to get protocol information and such. Then, using that information, to hack the PSN. The PSN was only brought down by Sony for security reasons, not by a DDOS attack or any of the such, it was simply because information was leaked from their servers in LA.

Although, research says the PSN should be back up this weekend, with some sorts of compensation to all PSN users.
[/quote]
I think psn plus for free 30 days :D[/quote]
That was one of the 2. Other is a complimentary download for certain regions.

Source

Read full topic

The PSN was only brought down by Sony for security reasons, not by a DDOS attack or any of the such, it was simply because information was leaked from their servers in LA.

Although, research says the PSN should be back up this weekend, with some sorts of compensation to all PSN users.[/quote]
I think psn plus for free 30 days

+1 if you’re glad Anon won
[/quote]
This wasn’t Anon.[/quote]
As said, it was done via a hacker that actually found a debug mode within the PSN via the PSP. Using this debug mode, most likely wrote a plugin to dump any data he could get threw the USB onto his PC or something to get protocol information and such. Then, using that information, to hack the PSN. The PSN was only brought down by Sony for security reasons, not by a DDOS attack or any of the such, it was simply because information was leaked from their servers in LA.

Although, research says the PSN should be back up this weekend, with some sorts of compensation to all PSN users.

item.title: Sony Admits Private PSN Info Has Been Stolen - All Of It
item.dc:creator: @CoonHunter CoonHunter
item.description:
@CoonHunter wrote:

[quote=“The Wanderer, post:58, topic:392746”][quote author=vamp256 link=topic=489915.msg3586716#msg3586716 date=1304233643]

All in favour for N64 for best console.

+1

+2

+3
[/quote]
+4
I have a Pokemon N64.

I have a question, how did they hack into the network? Did the use the user/kernal PSP/PS3 keys? Also why has it been down so long? Just wondering, I have a few ideas, but I am not the best educated on this type of matter.[/quote]
The PSN is down while they are re-working the entire system with better security. As for the user/kernel keys, they are only usable for signing homebrew and such, not for hacking into the PSN. Although, the keys might have helped with breaking down the firmware’s code to the point they could figure everything out to do so.

Read full topic

[quote=“B2300 T4nk, post:48, topic:392746”][quote author=drubrkletern link=topic=489915.msg3584269#msg3584269 date=1304040058]

w.o.w (not world of warcraft, i’m just putting periods after my letters). Sony is a good company, they just got caught off gaurd. It happens, it’s life, it’ll be big news for a couple of weeks, then it’ll calm down, everybody will be playing their black ops again.

When they don’t encrypt files? Don’t think so.

WHAT!?!?!

THEY DONT?!?

…

True, I agree they lack security, but they got what they deserved

Yeah, isnt that why mw2 got hacked on ps3?

[/quote]Its also hacked on the Xbox so stfu.[/quote]
No need to flame; im a ps3 fan as much as xbox, wasnt bagging on ps3, i was just asking a simple question, herp derp.

item.dc:creator: @jamie0910 jamie0910
item.description:
@jamie0910 wrote:

I lol at the video when anonymous states they are after sony, and not after “us, the customers”. But then why do they obtain 70 million people’s personal details and stop access to psn for all these users? And why do during the spring break? Why make customers worry about their statements, thinking some sad hackers will swipe their card. This should be treated as a robbery, and a serious crime. Fuck anon. Fuck anonymous.
